Controversy Explanation: Students and faculty claimed Bush was unqualified to speak at commencement because of her politics. Bush declined the invitation after the pushback.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The college dean said: "Mrs. Bush is quite qualified to be the school’s commencement speaker."

Controversy Explanation: The university rescinded its invitation of Goodwin to deliver a commencement speech after Goodwin admitted to committing plagiarism and students complained.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters. The university president stated: "We thought better to just cancel the appearance than to have her talk in front of our students and their families."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Wise to deliver a commencement speech because of Wise's views on abortion. Wise spoke successfully.
Members of the Black Student Union demanded the mural, which depicts a Ku Klux Klan rally, be removed. The university refused to remove the mural.
Public Response: Neutral.  In a statement the university's chancellor said: "The major issue running throughout all of the discussions and conversations over these last several weeks is not, in fact, the Benton mural. It is instead the state of diversity on our campus. The real issue, the real test of character, for Indiana University Bloomington is the strength of its commitment to diversity."

Controversy Explanation: Students and the Associated Student Body did not want the mural, depicting the wealthy sitting on toilets, defecating on huddled masses of poor people below, hung in the college's student center. An agreement was made to sell the mural but the college's mural program asked that it not be sold. The mural was relocated to the art department.
Public Response: Appeased Protesters.  In a statement the college's interim president said: “It’s a way of improving a lecture hall that has decor and colors from the ’70s.” He later added, “Art has a way of getting recycled over time. It could go down for another display and then get put back up again.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cornell Review and the College Republicans invited Coulter to speak about the controversy over the Confederate flag flying above South Carolina's state capitol. Students opposed Coulter's views on race and the Confederate flag. Coulter was heckled throughout her speech and, during the Q&A, oranges were thrown at the podium and the stage. One audience member lunged at the platform where Coulter was standing, but campus police restrained him and removed him from the room. A different auidience member then began talking over Coulter. Coulter left before finishing her speech.

The university decided it would not sponsor a performance of the play, The Vagina Monologues, on campus because the play espouses beliefs contrary to Catholic Church doctrine. The university woman's group sponsoring the event moved it to a hotel ballroom and put on the event without the university as a sponsor.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The university president, when refusing to permit the event on campus, said allowing plays to be performed "speaks volumes about who we are, what are mission is, what we believe."

Controversy Explanation: After the play, The Vagina Monologues, was performed on campus the year prior, the university prohibited performances of the play on campus after alumni raised concerns. Students performed the play in defiance of the ban.
Religious groups including Priests For Life asked the university to rescind its honorary degree to Cross because of Cross' pro-choice views. The university refused to rescind Cross' honorary degree.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. A university spokesperson stated: "Charity and justice demand that we take her at her word.”

Controversy Explanation: Students contested the university's invitation of Fiorina to deliver a commencement speech, claiming Fiorina's business background meant she was not an inclusive choice. Fiorina spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president said: "She meets all of our expectations and more."

Controversy Explanation: Students opposed the university's choice of Bush as commencement speaker because of Bush's conservative views. Bush's speech proceeded largely uninterrupted.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. The university president introduced Bush with the following: "Few families have so devotedly exemplified the university's commitment to public service as yours.. . . . interpersonal skills . . . commitment to inclusiveness, combined with your pragmatism and common sense, inspires us to hope that your presidency will expand opportunity for all Americans and bring peace and prosperity to the wider world."

Controversy Explanation: Police officer groups and family members of the victim opposed the college's invitation of Abu-Jamal to campus to deliver a commencement speech because Abu-Jamal was on death row at the time for killing a police officer. Abu Jamal spoke successfully.
Public Response: Supported Content of Expression. The college president said: "Many find, from looking at the record, the trial transcript and the various briefs filed in Abu Jamal's behalf, that the essential fairness of the case warrants critical discussion."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Foglietta to deliver a commencement speech because of Foglietta's views on abortion. Foglietta spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Marro to deliever a commencement speech because of Marro's views on abortion and, according to the society, Marro's bias against Catholics and Jews. Marro spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Johnson to deliver a commencement speech because of Johnson's endorsement of the “morning after” pill. Johnson spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Edelman to deliver a commencement speech because Edelman's organization, the Children's Defense Fund, promoted contraceptives in public school health clinics. Edelman spoke successfully.

Students accused Albright of war crimes and demanded that the university president disinvite her from campus. Some students walked out during Albright's speech, while others walked through the crowd holding signs. One protester yelled objections during Albright's keynote address. Some of the protesters were removed from the event and escorted off the premises.
The university president did not permit a Planned Parenthood representative to speak on campus because of the organization's pro-choice views.
Public Response: Mistaken on the Law. The president of the university published an op-ed that starts: "Censorship concerns the banning of ideas or viewpoints. Sponsorship is concerned with organizations making use of another organization's name and facilities. Normally, non-sponsorship occurs not because of an organization's ideas, or even because of its people, but rather because of its actions.

Controversy Explanation: Greene believes she was disinvited by the university administration because of her books, which discuss feminism, sexuality, and war.
Public Response: Condemned Content of Expression. The university told Greene her invitation was revoked because her “ideas may be different from the ideas of Harding University."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Winkler to deliver a commencement speech because of Winkler's views on abortion. Winkler spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the college's invitation of Kerrey to deliver a commencement speech because of Kerrey's pro-choice views. Kerrey spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Nelson to deliver a commencement speech because of Nelson's views on population growth. Nelson spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation of Mitchell to deliver a commencement speech because of Mitchell's views on abortion, parental notification, and fetal tissue research. Mitchell spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society opposed the college's invitation of Jackson to deliver a commencement speech because of Jackson's pro-choice views. Jackson spoke successfully.
Students petitioned the university to replace Rogers as its commencement speaker because they felt he wasn't a mature choice. Rogers spoke without disruption.
Public Response: Supported Speaker (or Artist) as a Person. An administrative statement included: "He [Mr. Rogers] has earned every major award in the television industry, including two George Foster Peabody Awards."

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Willis to deliver a commencement speech because of Willis' views on abortion, contraception, and priestly celibacy. Willis spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Castro to deliver a commencement speech because of Castro's views on abortion. Castro spoke successfully.

The college administration revoked Tammeus' invitation to speak at commencnement after the Cardinal Newman Society declared Tammeus an "offending" speaker who violates  “Ex Corde Ecclesia,” a 1990 Vatican document stipulating tighter restrictions on church-connected colleges, becasue Tammeus had written a series of reports on Catholic priests and AIDS for the Kansas City Star and had also written critically of Catholic practices and doctrines.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Caldera to deliver a commencement speech because of Caldera's views on abortion and gay rights. Caldera spoke successfully.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Leahy to deliver a commencement speech because of Leahy's views on abortion. Leahy spoke successfully.

The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the college rescind its invitation of Garibaldi to deliver a commencement speech because of Garibaldi's backing of "right-to-die" rulings. Garibaldi spoke successfully.
Protesters called Albright a war criminal and said she was unwelcome at Berkeley. Albright finished the speech but was heckled throughout.
The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Annan to deliver a commencement speech because of Annan's views on abortion.

Kissinger withdrew from a speaking event set to take place at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Presidential Library, located on campus, because the university told him that planned protests against his foreign policy would "endanger public safety." A journalism professor who had organized a student teach-in to plan questions for Kissinger disputed the chancellor's assertion that student's were planning a violent protest. The professor told reporters that the students were “not trying to shut it down . . .[but] were trying to get [Kissinger] to speak more.”
Public Response: Neutral (Disingenuous). The university chancellor stated: “It is deeply disturbing that any group of people can, by threatening to endanger public safety, dictate to a university community who can and cannot be heard.”

Controversy Explanation: The Cardinal Newman Society demanded that the university rescind its invitation to Reno to deliver a commencement speech because of Reno's views on abortion and because her department allegedly targeted pro-life protesters. Reno spoke successfully.

Pro-life students and alumni objected to the university's invitation of Quindlen to deliver a commencement speech because of Quindlen's pro-choice views. Quindlen withdrew from speaking at commencement.
Public Response: None. An article reported that "University officials declined to comment on her decision."

Controversy Explanation: Turner, media mogul and owner of the Atlanta Braves baseball team, withdrew from delivering a commencement speech because of student protests over the Braves' team mascot.
Public Response: Encouraged (or Approved of) Self-Censorship. The college president said in a statement: “As a result of the comments made about our decision to invite Mr. Turner, we have all gained a keener insight into the concerns many in the community have about Native American issues on campus, both in the curriculum and in other areas.”
